Elliotte Harold wrote:

> Let me ask you this. How would you feel about making "private" just a
> suggestion? i.e. why not allow anyone to invoke any private method from
> any class they want to? Of course, they would know when doing this that
> they were doing something skanky. Would you be happy with such a
> language? If not, why not? And why is a naming convention good enough to
> keep packages and classes unpublished if it's not good enough to keep
> methods unpublished?
> 
> If you think the private keyword should be just a suggestion, then I
> think we will just have to agree to disagree at this point. But if you
> don't think private is unnecessary, then I think there's a contradiction
> in your philosophy that's worth exploring further.

I think Smalltalk does this. If you want to mark methods private, you 
put them in a protocol that suggests they shouldn't be used directly. I 
don't have experience with the resulting code or the people that use it, 
but I notice that much good Smalltalk (really good, tested Smalltalk) 
has been written.
